questiontext.text: Which of the following countries are not amongst the three countries which were the worst affected in terms of the total number of outbreaks of African swine fever?

generalfeedback.text:
We find the top three countries using the following code

Outbreaks <- read.csv("Outbreaks.csv")

SwineFever <- filter( Outbreaks, disease == "African swine fever" )

SwineFever %>% 
  count( country, sort=TRUE) %>%
  slice_head( n=3 )

We find that the three counties worst affected were Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

questiontext.text: Based on your plot produced for Exercise 1 part b), which of the following statements is true?

generalfeedback.text:
We can produce the map of cases for the Baltic states using the following code:

SwineFever_Baltic <- SwineFever %>%
  filter( country %in% c( "Estonia", "Latvia", "Lithuania" ) )

ggplot( SwineFever_Baltic, aes( x=longitude,y=latitude ) ) +
  annotation_map_tile( zoom=6 ) + geom_spatial_point( ) + 
  labs( x="Longitude", y="Latitude" )

From this plot we conclude that most of the cases are located in the east of the Baltic states, with almost no cases observed in the western half of Latvia.

answer.text: Most of the swine fever cases are located in the west of the Baltic states.
Most of the swine fever cases are located in the east of the Baltic states.

questiontext.text: Is it reasonable to conclude that the point process describing outbreaks of African swine fever across Latvia is homogeneous?

generalfeedback.text:
We first create a ppp object by adapting the code in Section 4.6.4 of the lecture notes:

Latvia <- read_sf( "Shapefiles/gadm41_LVA_0.shp" )
Latvia <- Latvia %>% 
  st_simplify( dTolerance = 1000 ) %>%
  st_transform( crs=3857 )

SwineFever_transformed <- SwineFever_Latvia %>%
  st_as_sf( coords=c("longitude","latitude"), crs=4326 ) %>%
  st_transform( crs=3857 ) %>% 
  st_coordinates( )

Latvia_ppp <- ppp( SwineFever_transformed[,1], 
                   SwineFever_transformed[,2], 
                   window = as.owin(Latvia) )

We can then derive and visualize the quadrat counting estimate:

par( mai=c(0.01,0.01,0.5,0.01) )
Latvia_Quadrants <- quadratcount( Latvia_ppp, nx=7, ny=5 )
plot( Latvia_Quadrants, 
      main="Quadrat counting for swine fever outbreaks across Latvia" )

From this plot we conclude that there are large spatial differences in the intensity with almost all cases located in north-eastern Latvia. Consequently, we conclude that the process is non-homogeneous.

answer.text: Yes
No

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is true when considering the rate of violence per 1000 people per départment?

generalfeedback.text:
We can produce the map using

France <- read_sf( "Shapefiles/gadm41_FRA_2.shp" ) %>% st_simplify( dTolerance = 1000 )

Crime_France <- read.csv( "Crimes France.csv", header=TRUE, fileEncoding = "UTF-8" )

France <- inner_join( x=France, y=Crime_France, by=c("NAME_2"="Department") )

ggplot( ) + 
  annotation_map_tile( zoom=6 ) +
  geom_sf( data=France, aes(fill=Violence.per.1000.pop) ) + theme_bw() +
  scale_fill_distiller( palette="Reds", trans="reverse" ) + 
  theme( axis.title=element_text(size=15), axis.text=element_text(size=15) ) + 
  labs( x="Longitude", y="Latitude", color="Violence per 1000 people" )

The map shows that the highest violence rates were observed for Paris. High rates were also recorded along the French Riviera, around Paris, and in the northern départments close to the border with Belgium.

answer.text: Brittany is a hotspot for violence
Departments close to the border with Belgium recorded quite a high rate of violence
High rates were recorded along the French Riviera
The highest rates were observed in and around Paris
